—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-

The high interest rates on home loans of 13.5% and above have and are placing the recipients in a financially disastrous position, as thousands have lost their homes and thousands more will do so if these appalling conditions continue for the young and established home purchasers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians that no Government or Opposition in a power position should continue to tolerate this cruel, vicious procedure that shatters the very structure of family life, from the farmers to the city dwellers.

We need a five year period to reduce this absurdity by tackling it at its source. Firstly, interest repayments on home loans to be reduced by 2% annually for the next five years or until it is down to 8% or less.
This would, or should diminish union demands, and cause no hazard for investors, who could reinvest in Government projects, or other worthwhile ventures and also ease the burden on Social Securities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related tests in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that give the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia army barracks.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 180 citizens) and Zakharov (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the Media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 34 citizens) and Robertson (from 424 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, contrary to the well-being and wishes of the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate rejects this Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of West Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous, divisive and unnecessary proposal, the provisions of which are dictatorial, harmful and against the true interest of the people of Australia.
Your petitioners pray: That the Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, of the Parliament of Australia assembled:

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the storyline'' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 13 citizens) and Robertson (from 106 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986/87 budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Puplick (from 180 citizens) and Ryan (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operation of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that woodchipping and clearfelling will destroy the Otway Forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism. Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect theOtway Forests for the future and refuse any licence to export woodships from the Otways.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we support the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, which will:
protect individuals against violation of their rights by the impact of laws or by the actions of governmental institutions;
be effective in implementing Australia's international obligations to properly secure fundamental rights and freedoms and
provide an educative charter.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should support the passage of this Bill at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Reform
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that:
The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, e.g. petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace and Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that in the International Year of Peace, young Australians face an uncertain future due to:
1. a continuing arms race between the super-powers which threatens to extend into outer space
2. military expenditure continuing at ridiculously high levels
3. continuing testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons
Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to do everything possible to make our future more certain, by:
1. encouraging peaceful dialogue through diplomatic channels as the means of solving issues
2. persuading all developed countries to spend less on armaments, and more on basic needs like food, health, shelter and education for all people of the world
3. promoting the extension of agreements to reduce testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens shows that the citizens of the Northern Territory-
recognize-
(i) that nuclear peace for the world will come through adequate, supervised disarmament of nuclear weapons;

(ii) that arms limitation arrangements between the United States and the Soviet Union specifically provide for verification, and the general purpose of the facilities at Pine Gap contribute to this objective;

(iii) among the functions performed are the provision of early warning by receiving from space satellites information about missile launches and the provision of information about the occurrences of nuclear explosions which assist in nuclear test ban monitoring, supports nuclear non-proliferation measures and contributes to global stability-

and urge the Australian Government to give an unequivocal commitment to renew the lease on the joint defence facility for a further term of ten years when the present lease expires on 19 October, 1987.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular-
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50 per cent in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners' Pharmaceuticals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-
There should be no introduction of payment for pensioners' pharmaceuticals.
The proposed deletion of 46 products from the Pharmaceuticals Benefits Scheme will cause great hardships to pensioners.
There should be no substituting of cheaper drugs for those prescribed by the doctor.
There should be full testing of all pharmaceuticals by the Australian authorities before they are released on the market.
And that Australia should develop its own manufacturing industry in pharmaceuticals and stop relying on all overseas multinational drug companies.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Postal Facilities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate of Australia assembled.

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland showeth that Post Offices and Agencies should be located for the convenience of the public and should not be closed merely to help Australia Post make a greater profit.
Your petitioners thereby humbly pray that the Australian Senate will resist all moves to close local postal facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, left for South America and Europe on official duty on 10 September and will return on 4 October. In his absence, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, will be the Acting Minister for Trade.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister stand by his reported comments on spending cuts which were in the Age newspaper of 8 September, some of which I will quote? The Minister is reported to have said:

QUESTION.PARA: Whether you glorify it with the expression mini-Budget or not, there is room, I believe, for further cuts in certain areas of Government expenditure.

A little later it is reported that Senator Button said that the Government could have been tougher on spending in the Budget. Perhaps the Minister will also confirm that in the AM program of the same morning he said:
We could have further cuts in government expenditure which would be in particular areas which were not touched in the Budget round of expenditure cuts.

Does the Minister stand by those comments which were reported or broadcast on 8 September? I further ask: Will the Minister try to convince the Government that a mini-Budget should be introduced as soon as possible as, to quote what he said on that same AM program, it is better to do these things sooner than later?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, of course, very important to determine what fiscal year one is talking about. Twice since we have been in government we have had so-called May statements in relation to expenditure. Under the previous Government there were statements in relation to expenditure at various times. For example, I recall the activities of the now famous so-called razor gang which went on for many months. Those things have to be determined by governments at particular times. In looking at fiscal year 1987-88, it may well be that the Government has to bring forward some expenditure reviews into the second half of this financial year. The expression `mini-Budget' was used by Senator Chaney and by the journalist concerned in relation to the comment I made. Perhaps it was open to misinterpretation in that some people attach particular significance to the expression `mini-Budget'. The point I was trying to make was that it was not my expression but hers, and it would be called that, whether one liked it or not, by some journalists.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and others have said, and as I have said, there is the possibility, as there has been in previous years, of an expenditure statement in the first half of calendar year 1987 which would relate to the full financial year starting on 1 July 1987. To that extent I stand by the statements I have made.

Senator Chaney also specifically directed my attention to the question of whether further expenditure cuts might have been possible in the current Budget. If one goes back even two or three weeks, the community and indeed the Opposition were somewhat surprised by the extent of the constraint exhibited by the Government in the Budget, particularly in respect of outlays. From that point of view it was and is regarded as a very tight Budget. That does not mean that there cannot be an ongoing review of Commonwealth expenditures. There may be areas of Commonwealth expenditure which can be further examined, but that is for future Budgets or future expenditure reviews, if the Government decides that is desirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's attempt to push his words back into the next financial year, but I would remind him that in the AM interview to which I referred he specifically said that he had made his comment in light of the question about what the Government had to do in the next six months or so. In response to a later question about whether he was perhaps pushing for these to culminate in some sort of mini-Budget within the next six months, he said, and I quote in part from his answer, `I think it might be a desirable course'. I ask the Minister again the question he did not answer: Will he seek from the Government a mini-Budget because it is better to do these things sooner than later and he has indicated that that is his personal view?

—I have nothing to add to what I said in my original answer. I suspect that there is always in respect of governments room for expenditure review and further expenditure constraints in various sectors. That is something the Government could examine probably within the next six months and make a decision about. The next six months, of course, takes us well into calendar year 1987.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to last Thursday's national unemployment figures, and ask whether the Minister can now provide the Senate with information on recent unemployment trends in the various States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In August 1986-the most recent month for which figures are available-Queensland's unemployment rate soared to 9.4 per cent. That is the fifth consecutive month that Queensland has recorded the highest unemployment rate of any State. So since April Queensland has had the worst unemployment record of any State. Moreover, in only three of the 35 months since the last election in Queensland has Queensland had an unemployment rate below the national average. So for 11/12ths of the time since the last Government was elected in Queensland, the unemployment rate has been above the national average. When the Queensland Premier made his policy speech in 1983, less than 15 per cent of Australia's jobless were living in Queensland, and that figure has now risen to almost 19 per cent. That is what the Bjelke-Petersen Government has done to the Queensland work force in the past three years-it has concentrated an extra 5 per cent of the nation's total unemployed in that State. Indeed, we have now reached the point where there are more people in Queensland receiving unemployment benefit than there are in the State of Victoria, notwithstanding the fact that Victoria's population is 65 per cent greater than that of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The response of the Queensland Premier to this-and it is pretty hard to get a new idea into his head-is to trot out the hoary old chestnut that the high unemployment rate and the high rate of unemployment benefit recipients in Queensland are due to what he calls `southern dole bludgers' moving up to Queensland to bask in the sun.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a verb in that sentence?

—I do not have the full sentence here, Senator Aulich; just a quotation from part of a sentence or a substitute for a sentence, which would be a more accurate description of the Premier's normal speech mode. The latest official information is that for people in the prime working age group-that is, the 20- to 34-year-old age group-some 5,200 persons have migrated from Queensland to other States where employment prospects are brighter. The population increase in Queensland is concentrated in the non-working age group. In other words, workers in Queensland have voted with their feet; they have moved out of Queensland and into one of the Labor Government States because they know that they have a significantly better opportunity of getting employment there than they have if they remain in Queensland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer him to an interview which he gave yesterday morning on the program AM about mining in Kakadu and proposals that he confirmed he had put forward to clear the way for mining-other than uranium mining-in Kakadu, subject to environmental constraints, as he put it. I particularly quote his words:

QUESTION.PARA: I would like, so far as the existing park is concerned, to see some assessment of the resources there to proceed.

He went on to talk about the fact that the economic health of the nation required that in some cases mining should proceed. In the light of the statement that the Minister issued this morning, with his colleague Mr Cohen, I ask him whether that statement means that the vast areas of stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park are now completely locked away from any assessment of their resources, that only very limited exploration will be allowed in the remaining stage 3 of the park and that mining is to be allowed in only one area-at Coronation Hill. Does this statement mean that the Government has rejected the proposals of the Minister and presumably also those supported by the Prime Minister? Can the Minister say whether the Government has made any assessment of the loss of potential earnings from this decision and the impact that this decision will have on, to use his own words, the `economic health of the nation'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision made by the Government and announced today is that no mining or exploration for any mineral will be allowed to take place in the present Kakadu National Park-that is to say, stages 1 and 2 that have been declared. That means that as a result there will not be any resource assessment flowing from normal exploration activity. The decision has been made to ensure that no such activity-exploration or mining-takes place. As Minister for Resources and Energy, I have regarded my responsibility as being to ensure that all relevant points of view are put to and considered by the Government when issues of this kind arise. As far as I am concerned, that objective has been completely achieved by the very careful consideration that has been given to this matter by the Government over the last two days.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular assessment that probably most crucially governed the final decision to treat stages 1 and 2 in that way but to leave the door open for further resource assessment in the proposed new stage 3 extension area was the assessment-it is part of the Press statement-that has been made by the Bureau of Mineral Resources on the basis of all known existing information, which is reasonably substantial so far as stage 2 is concerned and not quite as substantial so far as stage 1 is concerned, but still substantial enough to enable a general evaluation to be made. That assessment is that there is a very high level of prospectivity in the existing national park for uranium, but only a moderate level of potential prospectivity for gold, platinum, base metals and other minerals. The converse is true of the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral lease areas to the south, where there is only low to moderate prospectivity, relatively speaking, for uranium, but a very high degree of mineral potential for gold and platinum.

Given the Australian Labor Party's position on the mining of uranium and given also the obvious need in the country's current economic circumstances to actively pursue nationally significant deposits of other minerals, subject to environmental constraints, it was, I believe, a perfectly rational decision to distinguish as we did between the two areas. The enormous significance of the natural and cultural heritage of the existing national park has never been properly acknowledged by the Opposition, which has made it only too clear that it is willing to dig up everything in sight in the existing national park, as long as there is a buck in it for some of them. Unlike that particular perspective, we have adopted the view that the natural and cultural heritage significance of stages 1 and 2 outweighs any likely economic benefit that might flow from mineral development there. The same is not necessarily the case for stage 3. I believe that under those circumstances a decision has been now made which is not only in accordance with the views and feelings of the great mass of the Australian people but also one that is a model of economic rationality.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Apart from the reference to the BMR report, has the Government made any assessment at all of the loss of potential export earnings and the impact on the economic health of the nation from this decision, including of course the potential for uranium mining?

—Various figures have been floated around by various interested groups of one kind or another, but I am not in a position and the Government is not in a position to evaluate those and make any judgment about them. Any figures that one might see in relation to the potential return in terms of either employment or financial benefit from the mining of uranium in the existing national park are of course entirely academic, because quite apart from environmental considerations and the depredations that would represent on that very important part of our national and cultural heritage, it is the Government's policy, as is well known, not to allow any further uranium mining projects to occur, whether inside or outside national park boundaries or whether inside or outside the Northern Territory or anywhere else.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. In relation to the Government pursuing its policy of cost recovery in the airline industry, the Government has been accused of ignoring the impact of the new arrangements on small commuter operators. Will the Minister comment on the impact to date and the likely ramifications for the commuter airlines and the general aviation industry, particularly in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware that over a number of years both the previous Government and, indeed, this Government have pursued a policy of cost recovery in respect of the airline industry, and the Government did make some decisions recently that have been interpreted in certain quarters as creating difficulties for the commuter operators. The Government is aware of the difficulties which commuter operators are facing during the transition period of the new charging arrangements. It is in recognition of these difficulties that the Government has provided a subsidy of $2m which will halve the charges of commuter operators during the current Budget year 1986-87. While operators have faced large percentage increases in charges, this began from a low base and the impact on air fares has been small. Nevertheless, the Government has recognised that its decision does require a transitional stage in its application. Those increases were approved by the Independent Air Fares Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the new charges it can be substantiated that 1.5 per cent will be available for Sunstate Airlines, which I think has some particular application for the honourable senator, and one per cent for Skywest Aviation Ltd. There will be an increase in flag fall for Hazelton Air Services Pty Ltd of $1.20 and for Kendell Airlines of $1.40. For Aeropelican Air Services Pty Ltd, 2.4 per cent is available. The figure for Airlines of Tasmania is 3 per cent. The increase for these two operators also takes into account the effect of the national wage decision. I point out also that there has been a subsidy of $1.80 for Rottnest Airlines.

General aviation operators will remain on a fixed annual charge arrangement for this financial year. Consultations are therefore being pursued with the industry to develop the most appropriate charging arrangements for general aviation. Annual air navigation charges were increased by 17 per cent on 1 July 1986. The Government's decision to credit the departure tax revenue to the aviation industry and recent increases in aviation fuel excise will lift the cost recovery rate to around 100 per cent in the year 1986-87. So the Government is aware of the difficulties and is taking what practical steps it can, having regard to the economic conditions facing this country, to ease the burdens on the commuter operators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Durack, I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to today's statement issued jointly by himself and the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment which announced, amongst other matters, the extension of Kakadu National Park to include the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases, but excluded from the new national park area Coronation Hill, where BHP Noranda Pty Ltd and EZ Industries are currently exploring for gold and platinum. When was the decision to exclude Coronation Hill made, and by whom? What evidence, if any, does the Government have of platinum being present in commercial quantities at Coronation Hill? If there is no evidence of platinum being present in commercial quantities, why was Coronation Hill excluded? What evidence was considered of the effect of mining at Coronation Hill on the Alligator Rivers area, in view of the fact that Coronation Hill is located within the Alligator Rivers catchment area? Does the decision to exclude mining from stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu represent a backdown by the Prime Minister, or is the decision based on the expedient ground that, as noted in the joint statement, no commercially viable mineral deposits are contained within stages 1 and 2? Finally, do the recent decisions regarding the sale of uranium to France and the assault on the environmentally fragile areas of Kakadu National Park signal a departure from the Hawke Government's previous environmental commitment as demonstrated by its actions over the Franklin issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision relating to Coronation Hill was made by the Cabinet at about 8.35 this morning and endorsed by the Caucus at about 9.53. In both instances it was a decision in principle that was being endorsed because the Coronation Hill joint venture has not been fully proved up and the final formal decision by the joint venture partners to go ahead has not been made. Nonetheless, on all the evidence which has been made available progressively to my Department and to the Bureau of Mineral Resources, it is apparent that there is a very major gold deposit there which is clearly not merely of commercial viability but also of a nationally significant scale. Similarly, it is evident that there is a very substantial platinum resource there. Just how substantial it is is a matter for current assessment by the joint venture partners. It would be inappropriate for me to say anything more about that given the commercial character of these matters. All that can be said is that clearly the deposit is already discernible as a deposit of national economic significance and as such is appropriate to be earmarked on this occasion for exclusion from the park. Obviously, as stated in the announcement this morning relating to Coronation Hill, the project will go ahead only if it can pass muster against the provisions of the environmental impact legislation, which includes reference also to Aboriginal heritage considerations and matters of that kind.
—Would that apply to stage 2 or stage 1?
—I am talking about Coronation Hill.
—I know, but--
—Order!
—Just answer my question.

—I have lost the thread. The honourable senator has succeeded to that extent. The point I want to make about the environmental constraint is that what is crucial about the Gimbat-Goodparla pastoral lease area is the protection of the ecology of the South Alligator river system. That is the attraction of the Gimbat-Goodparla pastoral leases for the national park. It is not because of anything that is particularly dramatic or exciting about the rest of the pastoral lease areas as such. All sorts of comparisons could be made between that area and the existing stage 1 and stage 2, not least the existence of a great deal of prior mining activity having taken place up and down the South Alligator River valley. I think that sufficiently answers the first question.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question was whether the decision on stages 1 and 2 amounts to a backdown by anybody. The answer is no, for the reasons that I explained earlier in answer to Senator Durack. I am sorry that Senator Haines is so churlish as not to acknowledge the magnitude of the decision made on stages 1 and 2. It is a decision which is path-breaking in that it completely excludes the possibility of mining and exploration. I believe that is something that the Australian Democrats have regarded as devoutly to be wished. That having now been accomplished, they are unable to acknowledge with any grace the nature of the decision made.

Finally, I was asked whether this amounts to any kind of departure from the environmental commitments that this Government has made and honoured in the past. Clearly, that is not the case. The Government remains infinitely more sensitive to these issues than are its opponents opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not saying much.

—I appreciate that that may not be saying much given the rape and pillage that could be expected to occur under a Howard Administration, but nonetheless it is a substantial comment to make about our commitment, the sincerity of it and the way in which over the life of this Government we have made very many decisions which have earned us quite properly the plaudits of the environmental movement. The other aspect of this decision that ought to be acknowledged but has not been in the honourable senator's question or anywhere else is that this morning we also decided to proceed immediately to the nomination of stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park for the World Heritage List. That again is something for which people have been calling for quite some time. That decision has been made without equivocation or qualification. That will happen.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in theCourier-Mail of 12 September regarding the authorisation of a loan to Mr Michael Behan, a former National Party Senate candidate, by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries in contradiction of advice from the finance manager of Behan's pastoral company-Elders- his Commonwealth trading bank manager and the Rural Reconstruction Board? If so, will the Minister confirm that a part of the funds provided to Mr Behan was allocated under natural disaster relief arrangements? If that was the case, what action does the Minister propose to take?
—On a point of order, Mr President: I am not sure to what extent this question comes within the purview of the Commonwealth Government or, indeed, the responsibilities of the Minister for Finance.

—Speaking to the point of order Mr President: It appears that the payment was ultimately sourced under the natural disaster relief arrangements. In the case of Queensland, in the last financial year 75 per cent of the money in question would have come from the Commonwealth.
—If the Minister says that the matter comes within his ministerial purview, I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article was brought to my attention only this morning. I have not yet been able to check out all the facts and am therefore not able to answer fully the last part of the honourable senator's question about what action I propose to take. This would have been an extraordinary story if the events had occurred anywhere else but in Queensland. It appears that Mr Behan had a debt of about $702,000 and applied for an additional $145,000 loan-$60,000 of which was to be used to reduce his debt to the Elders pastoral company, the remainder to be added to the pre-existing debt. In a memo dated 3 March, the General Manager of the Agricultural Bank, Mr Dellit, wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: Despite the budget that Mr Behan has drawn up (assuming a run of good seasons), I do not believe it is possible to service borrowings of this magnitude even when the property is fully stocked. I note that Mr Behan anticipates a surplus of $70,000 (less June interest) in October. However, with interest accumulating at in excess of $100,000 per annum, there is very little for debt reduction.
In the final sentence of the memo Mr Dellit wrote:
The applications for further advances of $60,000 to reduce debt to Elders, $45,000 for carry on and $40,000 for restocking are declined.

Mr Behan, however, is no ordinary person. He is a failed National Party Senate candidate and currently an employee of the Queensland National Party, being employed as a northern district organiser. No doubt it was for that reason that Mr Dellit in a memo dated 21 March wrote:
This case was discussed this morning with the Honourable the Minister for Primary Industries who directed that the sum of $145,000, as applied for from the bank, be approved.
Moreover, on 24 April, Mr Dellit reportedly wrote:

Early this afternoon I was called by Mr A. Hegarty, Deputy Director General to the Department of Primary Industries in regard to the Behan case. Mr Hegarty showed me a letter from Mr Behan to the Minister giving his version of a discussion at the bank on the morning of 22 April.

To cut short all the details, it is clear that the Rural Reconstruction Board, the Elders pastoral company and the Agricultural Bank each recommended that no loan be granted on the grounds that there was no chance that Mr Behan could be viable and therefore repay his existing debts, let alone further debts. However, into that scene was intruded, in typical Queensland National Party fashion, the `getting public money mixed up with National Party money' philosophy for which Queensland has become notorious. The Minister for Primary Industries directed the bank to make the advance to Mr Behan. I understand that the Premier has described the $145,000 as a `lousy' amount. I remind him that another former associate of his is now in the slammer for having misappropriated an even lousier amount. I remind him also $145,000 might seem to be a `lousy' amount to Queensland National Party apparatchiks who are accustomed to sticking their fists in the public till but to other Queenslanders it is not a lousy or inconsequential amount, and it is not a lousy amount as far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned.

In response to the final part of Senator Black's question, I will be initiating inquiries through the Department of Finance. If I may interpolate, a number of Commonwealth governments have had difficulty dealing with the Queensland Government and the Queensland bureaucracy because it is at all times necessary to be diligently looking over the shoulders of Queensland officials to make sure they are not misappropriating or misusing Commonwealth funds, but it is impossible to do this with absolute certainty. I will be asking the Department of Finance to determine the facts insofar as it is possible, firstly, to see whether Mr Behan was in fact the victim of a natural disaster. I suppose in a sense he is the beneficiary of an unnatural windfall gain through his membership of a Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia. We have to determine whether there was a natural disaster which would have given him some provisional entitlement to a loan. Secondly, we have to check out the facts regarding the gross breach of normal procedures, clearly instigated by the Government of Queensland, if not by the Premier himself. When I receive that report I will consider what further action is necessary for me as an individual Minister to take or refer the matter to Cabinet for decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy, who represents the Attorney-General, to assurances he gave the Senate on the 21st of last month that the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry would have ample opportunity and sufficient time to provide to law enforcement authorities any material of a kind which is colourable, to quote the Minister, before it is wound up by the legislation that is still before this Senate. In view of the fact that the Commission now says that further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses would be necessary to make much of the material that it holds suitable for reference, what action does the Minister propose to honour the undertakings that he has given?

—I do not have a detailed brief on that but I will seek a response from the Attorney-General. On a question of order, having been pulled up in raising these matters in the past and since this Bill is still before the Senate, it may be an appropriate matter to take up in the remaining debate on this Bill rather than in the context of questions.
—Will you give me an early answer?
—I will certainly endeavour to-by tomorrow, if I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Has the Minister seen reports last week of an alternative Federal Budget put forward by the so-called New Right? Would the Minister care to comment on the effects of such a policy on the welfare of women and families in the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen that document put forward by a group that calls itself the New Right or some name to that effect. I think it is important from the point of view of the circumstances of women in Australia that Australian women be quite clear about what the proponents of this new fanatical ideology are actually up to and what effect their ideas would have on women if they were to be taken up officially-clearly, they are unofficially supported by the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard-and if by any misfortune to the Australian people they should actually be in a position to put them into effect.

ANSWER.PARA: The New Right-as we know, it is quite close to John Howard-is very hostile to women, services provided to low income people through the public purse and welfare payments to individuals. A few of the measures that it proposes in its alternative Budget include these: An end to indexation of pensions and benefits, with any rises left to the discretion of Cabinet, which would take $450m off pensioners, the majority of whom are women; the taxing of family allowances and the abolition of allowance for the first child, which would take $600m away from families; the abolition of--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much have you taken away?

—I am sure that Senator Walters would be happy to join forces with the New Right. Perhaps honourable senators would like to hear what she would like to do. One measure that Senator Walters would really like is the abolition of bulk billing in the health system and the reduction of the Medicare rebate to 60 per cent of the schedule fee. Other measures include the cutting of grants to advanced education in technical and further education colleges; the abolition of the participation and equity program, which is a program aimed specifically at disadvantaged groups in education; the abolition of the first home owners scheme; a cut of funding by half, under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement; and the abolition of all job creation and training programs.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting that Senator Walters and her cohorts shout and scream when the New Right's Budget cuts are proposed. It is useful, especially to those who have organised themselves outside Parliament House today, to complain about aspects of the Budget that did not fill their aspirations. They pay attention to what those on the other side of the chamber and their front runners, the New Right, really would do. Those who are concerned, as we are, about women on welfare, single parent families and people who need bulk billing in the Medicare system, should pay attention to the draconian cuts and the destruction of virtually all major welfare initiatives that would take place if the New Right managed to bamboozle the public and help John Howard, its real leader, into office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has there been a shipment of Queensland Mines Ltd uranium to France since the Budget decision to lift the ban on sales to that country? Has the Government been reimbursed in full by the company for the money it paid in compensation during the existence of that ineffective ban? If not, how much has been paid so far? Will the total amount be repaid by the company, despite today's lower prices? If so, when does the Government expect payment to be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether any shipment has been made. That is a matter for the commercial arrangements that are entered into between QML and Electricite de France, which is the French purchaser, subject, of course, to the necessary export clearance being received from the Government. I do not believe that any shipment has been made. However, I do not have that information. The honourable senator asked whether any money has been received. The basis of the arrangement between the Government and QML is that the moneys in question will be paid in full by 30 June 1987; in other words, this financial year. I do not have full details about whether there will be any progressive payments before then. The extent to which that can appropriately be put on the public record might be addressed in an Estimates committee later this week.

ANSWER.PARA: The amount will be repaid in full-that is, the $41m that the Commonwealth has paid QML for the uranium already transferred in the past couple of years from QML to the Commonwealth and put in stockpile. TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is posed against the background of a somewhat incomplete historical focus on the Higgins Harvester judgment by a member of the H. R. Nicholls Society. Is it not a fact that the Harvester judgment arose not from a wage case but from an application by a manufacturer for exemption from paying excise duty equivalent to import tax; in other words, a tariff application? Is it not a fact that, inherent in his consideration of the application, Judge Higgins had to consider the entitlement of a worker to a fair and reasonable income sufficient to sustain his family in reasonable comfort? However, besides addressing that question will the Government consider the burden that an equivalent tariff increase of 30 per cent or 40 per cent because of the drop in the value of the dollar is placing on the family? Will the Government also consider the fact that, in the last 10 years, the disposable income of a family with four children on average earnings has dropped by 11 percentage points and will drop a further one percentage point by this time next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure why this question was addressed to me. A part of it is relevant to my portfolio and the other part perhaps is not. The first part of the honourable senator's question was very learned and erudite and it sounds right to me so I do not have to do more than agree with the honourable senator about the circumstances in which the Harvester judgment came about. Certainly the criterion adopted by Henry Bournes Higgins in that case was one of a fair and reasonable income for a worker with an average family. I think it is probably true in aggregate that there has been a tariff increase of some 30 per cent or 40 per cent arising from the devaluation of the Australian dollar, but I would just caution against that figure being accepted in respect of a wide range of commodities and goods because there has been very variable behaviour across industries in respect of the effect of the devaluation and the tariff equivalent concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I can neither confirm nor deny the figure the honourable senator gave in respect of household disposable income but I accept the figure which he put to me. I do not know what conclusion he is asking me to draw from all that, whether it is that tariffs should be lowered on certain goods or whether the Government should be concerned about the other end of the equation, which is disposable family income. I will consider that further and provide the honourable senator with a more detailed answer in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the decision of the Government to permit the export of uranium to France, the decision to amend the Northern Territory land rights legislation to erode seriously Aboriginal control over mining and the decision forced on the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment by the Prime Minister to permit mining within Kakadu. I ask the Minister: Are the economic rationalists who dominate the present Government caving in to the pressure of the Australian Mining Industry Council and the arguments of the New Right by redefining our national priorities to permit export-oriented economic development irrespective of environmental or social cost? Finally, how does the Minister define the national interest? Specifically, how many millions of dollars of royalties would justify drilling for oil on the Barrier Reef or extracting minerals from Kakadu National Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of those issues that have been raised come within my responsibilities, either as Minister for Finance or as a member of the Expenditure Review Committee for that matter. I note that Senator Sanders objects to economic rationalists having any input into government policy. I can only conclude from that that he would prefer economic irrationalists to be in control of policy; in other words, people like himself and a lot of the others with whom he seems to surround himself and to whom he panders. Dealing with the financial aspects of the uranium decision, it is very rare that a specific policy has these effects: To take amounts off outlays-expenditure in this case of $66m-off the Budget deficit and off the current account deficit. Very rarely does any single decision have all those positive things going for it, and that was certainly one of the factors which the Government considered.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said earlier, I do not think that the other matters that were raised come within my responsibility as Finance Minister or as a member of the Expenditure Review Committee. If Senator Sanders wants to take them up, I suggest he refer them to the Ministers responsible or their representatives. But I would like to make one comment on a question of fact. Senator Sanders is insulated in that cocoon of middle class trendies, where he normally finds himself, who think that there is a bottomless bucket and that governments can go on spending money everywhere and economies can go on providing money for all sorts of good works without ever having any wealth generating process either within the government or within the community as a whole. He probably would not have noticed it there, but a large number of Aboriginal leaders are, in fact, in favour of mining.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Sanders having addressed a supplementary question-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is far from the original question and is not a supplementary question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDONESIA: ABDUCTION OF EAST TIMORESE STUDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of reports that an East Timorese university student, Antonio Gonsalvez, was abducted by plain clothes intelligence officers in Jakarta on Wednesday, 3 September, and has not been heard of since? Is the Government aware that friends and relatives fear for his safety and fear he may be tortured? As this enforced disappearance occurred two weeks ago, will the Australian Government, as a matter of urgency, seek a formal confirmation of the arrest of Mr Gonsalvez from the Indonesian Government, formally express concern for his welfare and ask that Mr Gonsalvez be granted access to lawyers and relatives?

—All I can say on this matter is that the Government understands that Mr Gonsalvez was arrested in Jakarta on 3 September, although we do not know the reasons for the arrest. Our embassy in Jakarta is continuing to make inquiries about him. We will keep the honourable senator informed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Minister's recent words of consolation to the textile workers of Wangaratta that he favoured getting the effective rate of tariff protection below 75 per cent. Did the Minister say it would be simplistic only to lower tariffs in restructuring the textile, clothing and footwear industries? If so, did the Minister have in mind any real or nominal wage reductions or the elimination of any costly and inefficient work practices-if so, which practices-or will any additional measures be confined to retraining and transition arrangements? If so, what will be the net economic cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must begin by conceding that I am not nearly as good as the people who dream up these questions. If the honourable senator is asking me questions about the net economic costs in a variety of hypothetical situations, I suggest he spend his time trying to work out the answers rather than asking me to do so. The question of wage reductions, as the honourable senator puts it, is not something within the purview of the Government in respect of the textile, clothing and footwear industries. The industries' workers are not highly paid. They are not only not highly paid workers by Australian standards; they are not highly paid by many international standards, in terms of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Government's wages policy is determined in the context of the prices and incomes accord and decisions and submissions are made to the national wage cases.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as work practices are concerned, the honourable senator can peddle that sort of line around as hard as he can go. There is not much complaint from textile manufacturers about work practices in the textile industry. In fact, I think the industry is very much more free from complaints about work practices than are other industries. So those are two areas to which I will not be giving much attention in respect of the textile, clothing and footwear industries. In any event, the question of work practices, apart from a general indication of government concern about matters in some areas, is essentially a matter for management and the work force to work out between themselves. That is what has happened in this country. That is why work practices in some industries are bad and in other industries they are not, because bad management has allowed them to develop in a number of places. That is not true, I believe, in the textile, clothing and footwear industries. Insofar as the general level of assistance which will be accorded to the textile industry is concerned let me say this: The so-called 75 per cent option was adopted by a wide range of people long before the recent devaluation of the Australian dollar. There has to be some consideration of the value of the Australian dollar in determining the final level of assistance. That level will also be affected by factors such as the period over which a phase down of tariffs will take place. It is also affected by what assistance, or otherwise, the Government might give in respect of a whole range of issues, including export assistance, labour restructuring and retraining assistance, marketing and things of that kind.

I make these points at some length because very rigorous attempts are being made in certain sections of the community, particularly sections of the community which have made a squillion out of the textile, clothing and footwear industries, to reduce these matters to simplistic issues. They are not simplistic. The disappointing thing is that the honourable senator in his question makes the most valiant attempt to reduce them to simplistic, ideological and idiotic assumptions about wages and work practices, which are not issues in these industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the recent edition of the Pharmacy Review in which the President of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, Jim Matthews, reports the approval by the Guild of the changes in the Budget to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and says that the changes were `equitable and workable'? In the light of the misinformation peddled by Opposition members regarding these changes, can the Minister elaborate on the new proposals for their edification?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the copy of the Pharmacy Review and it is not surprising that Mr Matthews, who is the National President of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, should agree with the changes that were made in light of the fact that they were made in consultation with and with the approval of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. In some cases members of the Opposition and, in other cases, members of the public have not understood the changes as they were written up. I think it is a pity that they have complained about those changes and in fact believe that many people will be worse off. The changes will result in a more efficient scheme and will give greater protection to chronically ill taxpayers. In fact, the changes do retain the assistance to pensioners and other disadvantaged people which existed in the previous scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The raising of the maximum charge from $5 to $10 does not mean, as many people apparently interpreted, that prescriptions will now cost $10. In fact, it is estimated that the average cost of a prescription will be around $7.30, as the cost of a large number of items will lie between $5 and $10. Under the safety net built into the scheme to protect the chronically ill, no individual or family, including concessional beneficiaries, will have to pay for more than 25 pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescriptions in one year. After that number is reached, the prescriptions will be free. The net result of that is that those people who have to have more than 25 prescriptions will be better off under the new scheme.

The scheme has been clarified in the post-Budget period and I think that there has been a general acceptance of it by the pharmaceutical industry, pensioner organisations and others. It is time that we all settled down to ensuring that people know the facts and know their rights so that they can get the full benefit of the new scheme. We should do this rather than indulging in misinformation and therefore disadvantaging the very people whom the scheme is designed to help.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to an earlier question about unemployment figures in Queensland, and the fact that in his reply the Minister was unable to say how many unemployed came to Queensland from the southern States. Is the Minister aware that a thousand people a month come to Queensland from other States? Has any analysis been done as to whether these people were employed when they left the southern States, and also how long is the average time of unemployment after they arrive in Queensland? DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Government strongly opposes the dumping at sea of radioactive waste and other radioactive matter. The purpose of the present Bill is to give effect to this policy, by amending the existing legislation which controls dumping in Australian waters and by Australian citizens.

The principal Act to be amended is the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981. The Act provides for protection of the Environment by regulating the dumping into the sea and the incineration at sea of wastes and other matter. It was supported on both sides of the Parliament and received assent in 1981. The present Government brought the Sea Dumping Act into effect in March 1984.

In August 1985 Australia ratified the convention on the prevention of marine pollution by dumping of wastes and other matter, which is commonly referred to as the London Dumping Convention. As a contracting party to the convention, Australia subsequently co-sponsored a resolution adopted at the ninth consultative meeting, held in September last year, which provides for an indefinite suspension of the dumping of radioactive wastes at sea pending further studies and assessments. Several other international conventions are also relevant.

In conformity with the Government's policy of vigorous opposition to the dumping of radioactive waste at sea, the Prime Minister signed the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone (SPNFZ) Treaty on behalf of Australia on 6 August 1985.

When it comes into effect the Treaty will, amongst other things, prohibit the dumping of radioactive waste at sea within the treaty area, including the territorial sea of contracting parties. Parties to the SPNFZ Treaty will be required to prevent the dumping of radioactive matter in their territorial seas and not to assist or encourage the dumping of radioactive matter at sea anywhere within the Treaty area.

Another international agreement, the convention for the protection of the natural resources and environment of the South Pacific Region, ``SPREP'', is currently at an advanced stage of drafting. This Convention would, amongst other things, regulate the dumping of wastes at sea and preclude the sea dumping of radioactive matter anywhere in a defined South Pacific region. The SPNFZ Treaty places a legal obligation on its parties to work towards agreement upon a SPREP Convention which will ban the sea dumping of radioactive materials.
The present Bill will amend the principal Act to enable Australia to give effect to prospective obligations under both the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and the SPREP Convention.

As it presently stands, the Sea Dumping Act prohibits the dumping of high level radioactive waste and other high level radioactive matter at sea, but, paralleling the London Dumping Convention, it allows dumping under permit of other radioactive wastes and materials. I should add that no such permits have been sought under the provisions of the Act.
I turn now to the substance of the amending Bill. The purpose of the Government is to prohibit the dumping at sea of radioactive waste.

As honourable senators may know, all substances are to some extent radioactive, although, for most, their activity is negligible. It is thus necessary to make a definition which will clearly distinguish the radioactive substances whose dumping is to be prohibited under the Act from all other substances. This is to be done by establishing a threshold radioactivity level of 35 becquerels per gram, which is just marginally above the natural level of activity of the common element potassium.

The unit of measurement of radioactivity, the ``becquerel,'' relates to the rate of radioactive decay of a substance. One becquerel represents one spontaneous disintegration of the nucleus of an atom per second.

So that honourable senators may be assured that the proposed 35 becquerels per gram threshold limit is very low. I can advise that the activity of ordinary granite may range up to 15 becquerels per gram or more, Australian beach sands, which are mined for their mineral content, may have an activity of about 30 becquerels per gram, whilst potassium chloride, a common constituent of fertilisers, has an activity of about 18 becquerels per gram. For comparison, the uranium yellow cake produced from uranium mines has an activity of about 22,000 becquerels per gram.

There should be no environmental effects attributable to the trivial radioactivity of dumped materials which are below the specified threshold level of activity. This definition is, in the view of the Government, fully consistent with the draft definition adopted for the purposes of the SPREP Convention.

The Act does not apply in relation to a vessel, aircraft or platform belonging to one of the Defence Forces, reflecting a similar exemption in the London Dumping Convention. However it will continue to be the practice that the Defence Forces will observe the requirements of the Act, as amended. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has initiated an exchange of letters with the Minister for Defence to this effect.

Another proposed amendment to the Act clarifies that disposal of material into the seabed, or subsoil beneath the sea, by the dropping of containers designed to penetrate into the soft sediments of the sea-floor, amounts to disposal at sea. The technical possibility of such a method of disposing of radioactive wastes has been raised overseas.

Consistent with the Government's view on the respective roles of Commonwealth and State authorities in offshore areas, the present Act provides a mechanism for disapplying its provisions to the extent that equivalent State legislation applies in relation to the coastal waters of a State.

(``Coastal Waters'' are essentially the territorial sea within the three mile limit.) This mechanism is to remain, but it will not apply to sections of the Act which prohibit the dumping, loading for dumping or incineration at sea of radioactive materials.

Having given thought to the prospective implementation of complementary Commonwealth and State legislation to control sea dumping, the Government has concluded that there will need to be some kind of memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth and individual States to ensure that administration is made as simple and efficient as possible for permit applicants and the administering authorities. The Commonwealth must also be satisfied that the obligations it has under the London dumping convention, and those it will assume under the SPNFZ Treaty and the SPREP Convention, will be fully met. Accordingly the wording of the relevant section of the present Act is to be amended to provide a discretion in its disapplication in favour of equivalent State legislation. The Commonwealth's intention is to exercise that discretion in favour of suitable State legislation provided that an appropriate memorandum of understanding on administrative procedures is also entered into with the State concerned.

Finally, a minor amendment to the Act will ensure that where State legislation does apply, it will not be necessary for the Commonwealth to issue a permit for the loading of waste in addition to the permit for dumping of that waste in coastal waters issued under State legislation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
