DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. DAME ANNABELLE RANKIN, DBE

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 30 August 1986, of former Senator the Hon. Dame Annabelle Jane Mary Rankin, DBE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 30 August 1986, of the Honourable Dame Annabelle Jane Mary Rankin, DBE, Senator for the State of Queensland from 1947 to 1971, and a Minister of the Crown from 1966 to 1971, places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to her sister in her bereavement.

Dame Annabelle Rankin was born in Brisbane on 28 July 1908. Her career is probably most notable for having attained a series of firsts in Australian public life, and I just illustrate some of those firsts which she attained. She was elected to the Senate for the Liberal Party of Australia in the 1946 Federal election; the first woman from Queensland to enter Federal politics. She was a pioneer in the involvement of women in Australian public life. In October 1947, a year later, she was appointed Opposition Whip; the first woman in any Westminster-style parliament to hold the office of Whip. In June 1951 she was appointed Government Whip, a position she held for 15 years. She served, as most senators do, on various parliamentary committees. She was created a Dame of the British Empire in the Queen's birthday honours in 1957. She was Australia's second woman to hold Cabinet or ministerial rank after Dame Enid Lyons, but she was the first woman responsible for an executive department when she became Minister for Housing in the Holt Government on Australia Day 1966. She held that portfolio until May 1971 when she retired from Parliament. On her retirement from Parliament she was appointed High Commissioner to New Zealand, being the first Australian woman to be appointed to a diplomatic post in another country, and she held that position with distinction until September 1974. In addition to her public career in the parliamentary sense, she had a record of considerable community services before she entered parliament, as a teacher, with the Girl Guides Association, the Young Women's Christian Association and various other bodies of that kind. Her community concerns were very important to her throughout her 25 years as a parliamentarian.

Dame Annabelle Rankin was a long-standing and respected member of this chamber who served her country and her Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, with distinction. Her parliamentary achievements were recognised in 1984 when the new Federal seat of Rankin in Queensland was named in her honour. On behalf of the Government I extend to her sister our sincere sympathy at the passing of a fine Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to express our support for the motion of condolence which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and to support his expressions of sympathy to Dame Annabelle Rankin's sister. Senator the Hon. Dame Annabelle Rankin was not known well to me. I met her only as a visitor to this place, but it is clear from anything one can read of her or, indeed, hear of her from her contemporaries that she was an outstanding contributor to this place and an outstanding person. There is a small biography of her which is entitled A Woman of Distinction, and I found in a critique of that book an article headed `A thoroughly nice lady'. On what I know of her I think she will be long remembered in both those terms-as a woman of distinction and as a thoroughly nice lady.

SPEECH.PARA: She had an outstanding career, which has been outlined by the Leader of the Government, and that career seemed to have left her kindness, her calm and her good cheer untouched. I think that alone is a matter of some distinction in this place. Born in Brisbane, she was the child of a politician, and that makes her one of the many people who have chosen to follow in the footsteps of a parent. One of the present female senators in this place, Senator Shirley Walters, is one who has followed her father into politics, and Dame Annabelle Rankin was another. Her work during the war was distinguished. After her experience with the Girl Guides Association prior to the war she did welfare work with the armed forces and travelled extensively doing that work. She was in the end responsible for the welfare of all women's services in Queensland. She was, as Senator Button has told us, elected to the Senate in 1946 and she held the various positions that he has outlined. As an ex-Whip, I would have to say that remaining Whip for 15 years shows a strength of character that I think is beyond the capacity of any other Whip I have met in this place and, again, it is quite remarkable that all who speak of her say that she left that experience the same nice person that she entered it. As I said, as an ex-Whip, and looking at the Whips in the chamber at the moment, I regard that as an outstanding achievement.

Dame Annabelle Rankin was not married and one of her anecdotes touching on this is, I think, a reminder of the kindness and ease that she showed. She described in an interview in this biography-she obviously gave a series of long interviews for it-an incident when during a campaign speech a very irate women interjected: `I wish you would get married'. Her response was: `Madam, thank you so much for thinking so kindly of me. A number of people have said that to me but they have always been men'. It was the sort of gentle but very effective response that all of us would wish we were able to emulate.

Dame Annabelle was a colleague of some honourable senators who are here still and, of course, was well known to some of the Queensland senators who are not her contemporaries in this place. I know that they wish to contribute to this motion of condolence.

It is obvious that Dame Annabelle Rankin inspired affection and respect among her colleagues. She inspired the same feelings among her staff. I am pleased that two of them are able to be in the Senate today. They are Trish O'Connor, who is well known to many of us because of her work with not only Dame Annabelle Rankin but also subsequently the late Senator Ivor Greenwood, and Mr John Partridge who served her as a private secretary. It is a tribute to her that they wish to be in this place on this occasion.

The Opposition is proud of the many firsts that were achieved by this notable senator from Queensland. She was a woman who in more difficult times for women made her achievements appear almost easy. We know that that cannot have been so and that she would have run up against the barriers that one always comes up against in political life. But she seemed to surmount those barriers with great grace and apparent ease. It is a matter of great regret to us that she has died but we are very grateful for the life that she led and for the contribution she made to Queensland and to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I too support the motion moved by Senator Button and supported by Senator Chaney. As has already been indicated, Dame Annabelle Rankin was a woman of many firsts. I will not go over that ground. She came into the political scene at the end of World War II. Significantly, that was also a time when women were coming into the work force. I suppose one might say that that was out of necessity. Throughout World War II women were in the armed forces and were taking the place of men who had to serve in the armed forces. Once that had happened there was no going back. When she came onto the scene it was a time of retraining, rehabilitation and an acceptance of the fact that women were in the work force and were there to stay. From her point of view it was a time to make sure that, among many other things, there were better facilities for working women in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The post-war period was also a time of assimilation of displaced persons who came here from other countries. That was a priority. Dame Annabelle took a personal interest in that and in the problems of migrants. In the book A Woman of Distinction, to which Senator Chaney referred, she mentions how when she was out shopping once she came across a young migrant girl in tears. It turned out that the girl could not make herself understood to the shop assistant. Dame Annabelle sat the girl down and asked her what she wanted. The girl said: `I want a thing to hold the cauliflower so that the water runs out and the cauliflower stays in'. Very shortly they were able to go and buy a colander. But then Dame Annabelle, in her inimitable style, said to the girl: `Why don't you come and play shop with me?' A time was then arranged for the girl to go to Dame Annabelle's house and there, in what soon developed into riotous play acting, the girl indicated the things that she would want in a normal household kitchen and these were taken from the shelf. From that play acting a bit of education in everyday English was achieved.

Dame Annabelle also worked in support of handicapped people, particularly for facilities in their homes so that they could use whatever strengths and skills they each had in order to live as independent a life as possible. She also gave great encouragement to Dame Enid Lyons when she was fighting for child endowment for the first child. As a senator she was able to pursue these concerns at the highest level in our land. But that did not detract from her parliamentary duties. When she was elected in 1946-47 she and her Queensland Senate colleagues constituted the entire Opposition, which meant that she had a pretty heavy work load on top of the normal duties of a senator representing a State. As has been said, Dame Annabelle was a Whip. She described it as an interesting job but not an easy one. Indeed, in the book A Woman of Distinction, in relation to the history of the Whip, she stated:

In England, in the days of one of the early Georges, and I can only give you this as I was told it, and purposely do not give the date because I am not sure, he was anxious about certain legislation which was going through the House of Commons. Knowing that the numbers were so vital for the government, he said to the member responsible for getting the numbers (he was not known as the Whip at that point), `Whip them from the hunting fields of England and the pleasant haunts of Paris', and so from that day onwards the term Whip became well known and the official term.
She then stated:
I can assure you that when I whipped I had nothing as exciting to contend with as the hunting fields of England or the pleasant haunts of Paris.

I interpolate here that some of us who have had the job of Whip here have had some of the more pleasant restaurants of Canberra come in the way of a successful count. She also said that Whips trust each other. I suppose that is something that those of us who have been part of that exclusive group have all learned. If the whole House is in uproar, the Whips can sort it out and get the show back on the road provided they trust each other.
Dame Annabelle was a contemporary of many people who are now famous names in our politics-Fadden, Menzies, Calwell and Hughes. Speaking of Hughes, she said:
He, like everybody else, has failings. At times I am certain he was difficult and hard, but these failings make us more human.

Dame Annabelle saw everybody as a human being. She did not look for faults in people but just accepted their make-up and the fact that faults are part of being a human being. She came into politics at a time when it was not as easy as it is at present. Quite rightly, many of us believe that it is not an easy job now. In those days travel was a lot harder. Most of the travel that she did around Queensland was by train, and it was before the time of diesel engines and air conditioning. She recalled that over and above the gold pass senators were allocated about #30 for travel which could be used on odd occasions for air fares. Of course, accommodation in the outback towns was not very good. As I have said, with only a few coalition members in the Senate, the work load was burdensome and constant. But she took her place and played her part. It has been said by the two previous speakers that she went on to become a Minister and then High Commissioner to New Zealand. I was privileged to represent my Party at her state funeral and, along with you, Mr President, to be one of the official pall-bearers. She was a great Australian and a great representative of my State of Queensland. Along with my colleagues, I offer my sympathy to her sister, Jean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I think we all agree that the death of Dame Annabelle Rankin brings to a close a remarkable life and career. It has already been mentioned that she was a trailblazer in many areas and a significant role model in others. Born in 1908, she came from a politically conscious family. It is perhaps because of that that she was spurred on and better able to take on the tasks that she set for herself. Her father, Colonel C. D. W. Rankin, was for many years a member of the Legislative Assembly for Burrum in the Queensland State Parliament, and he was also Minister for Railways.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Annabelle first entered Federal Parliament as a Liberal senator for Queensland in 1946. As Senator Button has already mentioned, a brief resume of her parliamentary career shows that she was Liberal Whip when her Party was in opposition and again when it took over government, and she was appointed Minister for Housing by Harold Holt. She retired from Parliament in 1971 and was appointed Australian High Commissioner to New Zealand. While for any individual this represents a remarkably distinguished career, it fails to reflect the really significant aspects of Dame Annabelle's career-her strength and the role that she played not only in the Parliament but elsewhere.

In her 25 unbroken years in politics, Dame Annabelle, as has already been mentioned, was the first Queensland woman senator, the first woman Government Whip in any British Commonwealth Parliament and one of the few women Ministers in the Australian Federal Parliament. She was also the first woman appointed an Australian High Commissioner. This analysis of her career shows how significant a trailblazer she was. It is something that few of us today are likely to emulate but, I suspect, many of us would envy. We would certainly envy her strength of character. We would envy the purposefulness of a woman who was able to take all those things in her stride. Even today, women in politics are underrepresented but when Dame Annabelle Rankin began, she was one of the first female senators and the first woman incumbent of many important offices.

Dame Annabelle, apart from contributing in the parliamentary and diplomatic spheres, was active in many community organisations, including the Girl Guides and the Red Cross. Throughout her life she maintained a particular interest in the welfare of young people, the disabled and the aged and was a regular advocate of their causes. Overall, Dame Annabelle was a pioneer, a significant role model for women, a magnificent contributor to Australian public life and community-minded in a way that we could all emulate. We much regret her passing and extend our sympathy to her sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in this condolence motion for Dame Annabelle Rankin. Dame Annabelle's life was characterised by service to the community. She was deeply involved in that service before she entered Parliament and, after a long and distinguished period in the Senate, she carried on that service after she retired from this place. In my lifetime, no Queensland senator has been better known, better loved or more respected than Dame Annabelle Rankin. Other honourable senators have spoken of her long parliamentary career. To me, she was a permanent part of Queensland political life. I first met her when I was a small schoolboy during the late 1940s shortly after she entered the Senate. She was a permanent part of the Queensland political scene during my adult life until her retirement in 1971, six years before I became a senator.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember Annabelle as a warm, friendly, happy person with a great store of common sense. She had a great natural dignity but she was very approachable. Anyone could come up to her and get a warm welcome. She was a very great credit to the Liberal Party of Australia. She was a great credit to the Parliament and she was a great credit to Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to join other honourable senators in expressing my sympathy at the passing of Annabelle Rankin. I would particularly like to express my sympathy to her sister, Jean, and to her other relatives. I pay tribute to a remarkable person whom I was privileged to know from 1946 over the three decades of her public career. This Parliament has produced some remarkable women of achievement-Enid Lyons, who comes immediately to mind, Dorothy Tangney and, of course, Annabelle Rankin. One must think of Annabelle Rankin with happiness because she had the gift of happiness and friendship. When I think of her in the immediate post-war years, I think of a titian haired woman of considerable attractiveness, both of personality and of presence. I think of her twinkling, sparkling eyes which always managed to capture the happiness of the day and of the smile on her face, yet she had an ability to lead and command on both sides of the Senate. As other honourable senators have said, she attracted warmth, affection and love.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney has expressed it best in remarking that perhaps the greatest tribute is not in the speeches we make here but in the fact that in the President's gallery we are privileged to have present two members of Dame Annabelle's ministerial staff whom we respect for their dedication and devotion. Trish O'Connor and John Partridge have travelled great distances and at great inconvenience to come here and to participate. We welcome their participation in this tribute. Annabelle Rankin had the capacity to attract devotion, dedication and that kind of friendship. Trish O'Connor sent me a note, which she will not mind my reading, which stated:
Ben Chifley used to walk Dame Annabelle back home to the Hotel Kurrajong each night.

As you would know, Mr President, from your long experience here, that signifies the kind of comradeship and bipartisanship that Dame Annabelle expressed in the Parliament. We often recite people's physical achievements, thinking that those are their monuments, rather than looking at their inherent personalities. It is remarkable that Dame Annabelle was a senator for 25 years, that during that time she was a party Whip for 17 years and was enormously respected as such, that for five years she was a Minister of the Crown-as Senator Button said, the first woman Minister; my memory is that Dame Enid Lyons was Vice-President of the Executive Council-and that she went on to be High Commissioner to New Zealand for four years. Those are great achievements but they are not the measure of the person. The measure is that those who walked and associated with Dame Annabelle are immensely the better for having known her. We are immensely the better for her friendship, the affection which she gave to us and the plain common sense which she brought to bear as a Senate Whip. We are the better for the fact that she was the best of colleagues. One could not have a warmer friend.

Dame Annabelle was State Secretary of the Queensland Girl Guides. She was active in the Red Cross and in the Young Women's Christian Association. She was always active in matters of human concern. SPEECH.PARA: I first met Dame Annabelle Rankin at the Kingaroy show. My remembrance is that she was able to make the shortest speech I have ever heard made by anyone who opened a show. I visited her in hospital not long before her death. She was certainly far from well on that day, but she was able to speak to me and she certainly appreciated the fact that I had paid her a visit. TALK.START.PARA: —Having been a Whip in the Senate, I would like to pay tribute to Dame Annabelle Rankin. I met her, as did Senator MacGibbon, when I was a boy at school. I remember meeting her when travel was difficult in Queensland and when she went to Mount Morgan. I cannot recall anyone anywhere in Queensland who disliked her. I am thrilled that some of her staff members are here today, particularly Trish O'Connor, who was one of the first staff members I met here when she was working for the late Senator Ivor Greenwood. I am particularly thrilled that they are here to hear the tributes that are being paid to Dame Annabelle Rankin this afternoon. —One of the advantages, or maybe disadvantages, that I have in this place is that there is nobody but myself to speak on my behalf. It has been a great pleasure for me to sit here and listen to the tributes that have been paid to this great figure, this person who has so obviously given of herself to the service of the people of Australia. It has been instructive to me to listen to those who knew her. I therefore am honoured to associate myself with the condolence motion which was moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and so ably supported by other honourable senators.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to pay my respects to the memory of the late Dame Annabelle Rankin because I had the honour to serve in the Senate with her from 1962, when I entered the Senate, until 1971, when she left the Senate to become the Australian High Commissioner to New Zealand. DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. LESLIE HARRY ERNEST BURY, CMG

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 7 September 1986, of the Hon. Leslie Harry Ernest Bury, CMG.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate express its deep regret at the death, on 7 September 1986, of the Honourable Leslie Harry Ernest Bury, CMG, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Wentworth from 1956 to 1974, and a former Minister of the Crown from 1961 to 1962 and 1963 to 1971, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family in their bereavement.

Mr Leslie Bury was born on 25 February 1913 in London and was educated at Queen's College, Cambridge. He was elected to the Australian House of Representatives for the New South Wales seat of Wentworth, representing the Liberal Party of Australia, in the by-election that was held following the resignation of the Rt Hon. Sir Eric Harrison. He gave 17 years continuous service to the Parliament and held various ministerial portfolios to which I will refer without specifying the dates. He was Minister for Air, Minister for Housing, Minister for Labour and National Service, Treasurer and Minister for Foreign Affairs until the government of the day was defeated. He also had non-parliamentary involvements, in the same sorts of areas, I suppose, as Director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Australian representative on the International Monetary Fund in Washington. He had senior Public Service posts in Canberra and was the President of the Australian Institute of International Affairs from 1949 to 1951. Mr Bury served in the Second World War in the Second Australian Imperial Force from 1943 to 1945.

I have only passing or slightly dim recollections of Mr Bury as a Minister, but I think it is true to say that from everything that was said about him at the time and subsequently he was a very workmanlike and decent Minister in the way in which he performed his role. He was a long-standing and respected member of the House of Representatives and of the Parliament. On behalf of the Government, I extend to his widow and family sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to support the motion of condolence which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). He has already outlined the political career of Mr Bury. He was of a generation of politicians which I very greatly respected. As the Leader of the Government has said, he was born in England but he served in the Australian Imperial Force during the war. It was my dominant impression of this place when I used to visit it during my father's period in the Parliament that the ex-service generation had placed a very distinctive stamp on this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the same comments could have been made in speaking to the condolence motion for the late Dame Annabelle Rankin because, in effect, in her duties she worked with the forces in Queensland. Of that group of people who saw war service very few are left in this Parliament. I can think of Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Gietzelt, Senator Kilgariff, the Opposition Whip, and Senator Withers. When the Parliament was peopled largely by that ex-service generation, it was a place of far greater certainty and was, in a way, very much more attractive. It may be a difficult way in which to learn one's certainties about life, but I think those Australians who served in that way knew what they wanted for the country and brought an attitude and an approach to politics that I for one found very attractive. In many respects, it was superior to what we have been able to re-create with the next generation.

Mr Bury was born in England, but he made a notable contribution to the country of his adoption. He came to Australia with a private bank. The Army took him away from that. Subsequently, he joined the then Department of External Affairs and then the Commonwealth Treasury. While working with the Treasury he became Executive Director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and Australian representative on the International Monetary Fund. Therefore, he entered this Parliament with a substantial background and experience across a range of areas. That helps to explain the considerable contribution he made to government during his period as a member of parliament.

Mr Bury succeeded Senator Shirley Walters's father to the seat of Wentworth. That is yet another of the personal threads that run through Australian political life and remind us what a numerically small society Australia has. He held a series of ministries, although his early ministerial career was broken by the fact that he contradicted Sir John McEwen in his concerns about the entry of Britain into the Common Market. It is one of my early recollections of politics that Mr Bury had to stand down from the Ministry and did not return to it until after the next election. After that time, he continued his ministerial career and held major portfolios.

His return was to the difficult task of establishing a new department. He was the first of the Commonwealth Ministers for housing, and organised a new department. Again, it is a reminder of the smallness of the society in which we move that he handed over that Department to Senator the Honourable Dame Annabelle Rankin to whom we referred and whom we remembered earlier in debate. Mr Bury's contribution in all of those positions was of the nature indicated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He was a most workmanlike politician. He was, in the view of his contemporaries, a man of great integrity. I know that he had the warm regard and respect of my father. When he was a candidate for Prime Minister, it was written of him that he would be firm in his judgments, uncompromising, but essentially fair and probably more humane than any other likely candidate. All that rings very true to me of the man I knew, although I did not know him well. I express to his widow and children the sympathy of the Opposition for the loss of a fine husband and father and a man who had the respect of his colleagues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I wish to be associated with the motion. Both the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) have alluded to the long and distinguished career of Les Bury. Significantly, as has been said, he came to us from what was known then and still is a little as the old country, and we adopted him. More than that, he adopted this country. He did not just come out to Australia. He served this country in many fields as the opportunities arose, although I do not suppose that one saw World War II as an opportunity necessarily to serve one's country as one would wish. However, he played his part in that respect. He held various positions in the Public Service and had a long and distinguished parliamentary career. My Party and I wish to be associated with the motion of condolence and express our sympathy to his widow and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) on the death of Leslie Bury. Like the death of Dame Annabelle Rankin, the death of Leslie Bury brings to an end a very distinguished career in Australian public life, both in and outside the Parliament. As has been mentioned, before Mr Bury entered Parliament he was the Executive Director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Australian representative on the International Monetary Fund in Washington. He held various senior posts in the Public Service in Canberra, including with Treasury and the Department of Foreign Affairs. Along with Mr Bury's two-year presidency of the Canberra branch of the Australian Institute for International Affairs, his background and war service equipped him well for the parliamentary career that followed.

SPEECH.PARA: As Federal Treasurer in the Gorton Government and later as Minister for Foreign Affairs, Leslie Bury was highly regarded. His earlier roles as Minister for Air, Minister for Housing and Minister for Labour and National Service show how versatile a parliamentarian he was. I join with other senators who have expressed their sympathy for his wife, Anne, and for their family in noting that we regret the passing of Leslie Bury.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are paying tribute to two very special people. Leslie Bury was a very special person-a person with qualities of character, intellect and integrity that deserve our full tribute today. In paying that tribute, I must also pay tribute to a magnificent wife, Anne Bury. She is an outstanding woman. She was an outstanding wife and supporter to Leslie and is an outstanding mother to four fine sons.

SPEECH.PARA: When I think of the times concerning Leslie Bury, my memory goes to two events, especially the one when Sir Eric Harrison went to London. A person came to me and said: `A young economist representing Australia at the World Bank is called Leslie Bury. I wonder whether you would meet him and talk to him. He might be interested in Wentworth'. That is how we met. That was a journey of friendship that we come to know in this profession.

More importantly, as has been mentioned today by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), I recall the incident when Leslie Bury sought to comment with difference from John McEwen regarding the European Economic Community. I recall vividly walking up and down Martin Place with the then Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, trying, in my amateur way, to talk him out of doing anything radical about Leslie Bury. We walked up and down Martin Place for about half an hour. I can still hear Mr Menzies-those honourable senators who knew him know of the cocked eyebrow and the thumb forward-saying: `You are very persuasive, my boy, but back to the surgery'. I knew that I had lost. But I had not lost, and this Parliament had not lost, because the quality of the man shone through. It was his integrity that led him to do that. It was his integrity that restored him to the Ministry afterwards. Perhaps it is a reflection on our standards that today that incident would not have been mentioned other than as a minor rebuke or perhaps a comment from some of us behind on the independence of spirit of the man himself.

In my experience, Leslie Bury was a quiet man. I do not mirror that, sadly. He was a man to respect, a man to measure, and a man to judge. Most of us tend to be noisy. In every sense, he was a gentle man, yet with the firmness of his convictions and a very high intellect. He was a man of great compassion and concern for people. Therefore, he was admirably suited to an era in which post-war reconstruction tried to take away the harshness that had been of the depression years and the war years.

Mr Bury achieved a great deal in his various portfolios. Sadly, in recent years, his health was poor. He was limited, therefore, in his ability to enjoy the fullness of life. I can only say that no man could have been luckier than he was to have had Anne as a wife, alongside him, and his four sons. I have benefited greatly from the friendship of Leslie Bury. This Parliament and the people of Australia will remember him as one of their outstanding members of parliament and citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew Leslie Bury not as a member of parliament but as a member of the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Those were the times when Albert Monk was President of the ACTU, Sir Harry Bland was Secretary to the Department of Labour and National Service and Leslie Bury was the Minister responsible for that Department. There is no doubt that, during discussions, it was perfectly clear that Leslie Bury had a very firm command of the potential importance of international labour institutions, such as the International Labour Organisation. Of course, at that time he was very much preoccupied with the other aspect of his portfolio-the national service aspect. That must have been a very worrying aspect. Nevertheless, honourable senators who were about at that time will recall that there were significant industrial problems as well, such as postal, transport, waterside and stevedoring problems. Of course, ultimately the portfolio responsibility for all of those problems rested with Leslie Bury. He gave his services to this country. His dedication to his task has been noted. I join other senators in this condolence motion and in conveying condolences to his wife and his family.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did organochlorine pesticides first become of concern to environmental health authorities in this country.
(2) When did the National Health and Medical Research Council commence to support a long standing policy of the Australian Agricultural Council for phasing out of such materials.
(3) What actual materials have been phased out since that date; what have been their substitutes and when has each individual instance taken place.

(4) Who has conducted further review into the health hazards of such substances, when did that review start and when is it expected to be completed? (See answer to Question on Notice No. 422, Hansard, 7 November 1985, p. 1804).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The potential for residues of organochlorine pesticides in food was recognised by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) as part of the Survey of Pesticide Residues in the Total Diet commissioned at the sixty-eighth Session in May 1969. The report of the Survey presented to the seventy-third Session in October 1971 resulted in a recommendation to the States for control of certain organochlorine pesticides. Subsequent Market Basket Surveys have shown a decline in the residues of organochlorine pesticides in foods, indicating that action taken to restrict use of these chemicals has been successful in this regard.

(2) The NHMRC has supported the policies of the Australian Agricultural Council since its inception in the 1960s. At its seventy-third Session in October 1971, the NHMRC noted that steps had been taken by State Departments of Agriculture to prevent contamination of food by organochlorine pesticides.

(3) My Department has collated information which will be deposited in the parliamentary library. Information provided by State authorities indicates that none of these pesticides has been totally phased out; it does show that the majority of agricultural uses have ceased. Information on substitute chemicals is difficult to obtain and would require considerable additional efforts by the States.

(4) The current NHMRC review of organochlorine pesticides began in December 1985. Recommendations of relevant expert committees were considered by the Public Health Committee of NHMRC in March 1986. Whilst the current information on aldrin, dieldrin, chlordane and heptachlor suggested that further restrictions on the use of these compounds are warranted, it is insufficient to justify precipitate action. It was further felt that any future actions should be scientifically based on hazards estimated from actual exposure data. Accordingly the Public Health Committee proposed the following action:
a. Agricultural Uses

The Australian Agicultural Council will be requested to provide justification for continuation of the specific uses of these products in agriculture which could give rise to pesticide residues in food directly or indirectly.
b. Household Uses

All State and Territory Governments will be asked to investigate the domestic uses of these compounds with a view to curtailing or further restricting their availability to the general public through relevant State and Territory legislation.
c. Urban Uses
State and Territory Governments will also be asked to investigate the uses of these compounds in the domestic pest control industry and the resultant human exposure which could arise from such usage.
The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission will be asked to investigate the occupational aspects of use of these compounds, particularly by the urban pest control industry.
Information on current uses and their needs, resultant human exposure and the hazards of alternative products has been requested and will be evaluated as soon as possible.

The Public Health Committee believes that when this information is available, the expert NHMRC committees would be well placed to reach sound conclusions and provide further advice on the necessity for further regulation of these compounds.

(3) When parental accommodation is provided, does it not overcome the trauma suffered by children who undergo operations, help them mentally and hasten their recovery.
(4) Is the introduction of such a scheme to cover parental accommodation actually saving money.

1986-1049 (to 6 August)

(4) The Africaner Weerstandsbeweging (which means ``Afrikaner Resistance Movement'') was formed in 1972 by disaffected members of the governing National Party. The particular issue which prompted the formation of the AWB was the dialogue with other African states which was then being pursued by the Prime Minister, B. J. Vorster. Its members also believed that the National Party was generally becoming too accommodating towards blacks. The AWB has never attracted a large following but it has risen to occasional prominence because of the extreme and racist views of its members and because of the involvement of some of its members in violence. In 1983 two former members were convicted of offences under the Terrorism Act and sentenced to 15 years jail each. In the same year the leader of the AWB, Mr Eugene Terreblanche, was given suspended sentences after being convicted of two offences related to the illegal possession of firearms. The meeting in London agreed on eleven measures which should be applied against South Africa and the Government is now considering their implementation.

(6) The Government is prepared to support comprehensive mandatory economic sanctions against South Africa in the United Nations context. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 3 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Resources and Energy detail what avenues of assistance may be forthcoming from both State and Federal Governments to aid the tin mining industry, which has been hard-hit by world trade movements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government announced on 3 March that it has agreed to provide $1 million in financial assistance to small scale tin producers within Australia who are experiencing difficulty in rationalising their mining operations in the wake of the collapse in world tin prices.

The Commonwealth assistance scheme is in the form of an interest subsidy on commercial loans and leasing arrangements for mine relocation and restructuring, and should assist small scale tin producers to maintain their viability through restructuring and diversifying their mining operations. The assistance provides for a 50 per cent interest subsidy on a loan of up to $20,000 to a maximum subsidy payment of $8,000 per eligible tin producer.

Following representations from the small scale tin mining industry and discussions with the Queensland Government, the Government considered the arrangements for this scheme and on 6 June announced a number of changes. The Government agreed to delete the initial requirement that, to be eligible for assistance, small scale tin producers undertake to relinquish their tin leases by 30 September 1989. The Government's decision recognises that the original provision to relinquish tin leases would prevent miners from diversifying/restructuring without the added security of existing tin leases and associated assets, and that some diversified/restructured operations would not be commercially viable without access to existing tin leases.

A further change to the scheme is that, in view of the continued uncertainty in the tin market, and the time delay since the scheme was initially announced, the Government has agreed to backdate the subsidy on relevant borrowings and lease payments to 24 October 1985.

The scheme will be administered by State Governments who currently have before them draft Financial Agreements to provide for the allocation of Commonwealth funding for the scheme. Once the States have agreed to these, it is expected the scheme will be in place shortly thereafter.

In Queensland, where the majority of Australia's small scale tin producers are located, the Commonwealth's assistance package is designed to complement a package of concessions announced by the Queensland Government on 4 February 1986 which provided for the deferral of royalties and mining lease rentals until 30 September 1986, and the writing off of interest and penalties associated with the deferral of these payments. The Queensland Government recently announced an extension of the period for deferral of royalties and lease rentals to 30 September 1987. The concessions offered by the State also provide that existing tin producers who leave the industry before 30 September 1987 will not be required to pay royalties on tin produced after 24 October 1985, and if mining leases or claims are surrendered the rental due for 1986 and 1987 will also be written off.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Education: De Facto Relationships

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the determined policy of the Department in relation to de facto relationships.
(2) How is this policy implemented in departmental assessment of individual claims for benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In relation to de facto relationships, the Department of Education implements policy determined by the Government. Specific provisions concerning de facto relationships are included in most of the schemes of educational assistance to individuals administered by the Department of Education, as described in (2) below. With respect to departmental staff there are also provisions in the various Personnel Management Manuals, which are common to all Commonwealth Departments.

(2) In two student assistance schemes governed by legislation, namely the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and the Postgraduate Awards (PGA) scheme, and in the non-legislated Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme (ASEAS) there is a common definition of ``spouse'' which includes acceptance of de facto relationships where there is a child of the relationship or two years' cohabitation. Such relationships may enable a recipient of assistance to qualify for certain allowances, namely dependent spouse and fares allowances under TEAS and ASEAS, and dependants, travelling and establishment allowances under the PGA scheme. In addition, under TEAS and ASEAS, the independent rate of allowance is paid where a student is living in a de facto relationship and there is a child of the relationship. In all income tests where a spouse's income is taken into account (including the parental income test for the non-legislated Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS) and the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) Scheme) the term includes a de facto spouse.

For the assessment of benefits under the Aboriginal Study Assistance Scheme (Abstudy) no distinction is made between married students and those living in de facto relationships, in recognition of differing social patterns within Aboriginal society. The relevant benefits are living and dependants allowances. Students who are 18 years or over or ``married, living in a de facto relationship or widowed, divorced, single, separated but with one or more dependants'' attract a higher rate of living allowance payable. Students also receive a dependants allowance in respect of a dependent spouse or de facto spouse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Victoria consistently had an unemployment rate below the national average in recent years; if so, for how many months consecutively has the Victorian unemployment rate been below the national average, and for how many consecutive months has Victoria had the lowest unemployment rate of all the states.
(2) What are the reasons for the unemployment rate in Victoria being below the national average.
(3) Could the national jobless rate be lowered to the Victorian level without the national economy suffering adverse side effects.
(4) What barriers, if any, exist to prevent the jobless rate in other states from falling to the Victorian level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Victoria has had an unemployment rate consistently below the national average in recent years. The Victorian unemployment rate has been below the national average for 58 consecutive months (from October 1981 to July 1986) and Victoria has had the lowest unemployment rate of all the States for 38 consecutive months (from June 1983 to July 1986).
(2) A combination of factors contribute to Victoria having an unemployment rate below the national average.

Industries have been affected to varying degrees by poor economic growth over the decade to 1983 and differences in industry composition of the State economies are reflected in differing State unemployment rates. Victoria's unemployment rate in the decade to August 1983 has for the most part been below the national average and the peak unemployment rate for Victoria was 9.7 per cent in May 1983, 0.6 percentage points below the Australian unemployment rate of 10.3 per cent at that time. Full-time employment growth in Victoria in the last three years of economic recovery has been slightly higher than the national average, at 8.4 per cent in the three years to July 1986 compared with 8.0 per cent for Australia.

Differences between States in their labour force participation rates may also give rise to different unemployment rates, although this has not contributed significantly to the lower unemployment rate experienced in Victoria.

Long-term unemployment is also not at present as great a problem in Victoria as it is in Australia as a whole, due to the impact of the 1982-83 recession on long-term unemployment being greater for other States than for Victoria. In June 1986 the proportion of the unemployed within the 12 months or longer duration category was 24.1 per cent for Victoria and 29.2 per cent for Australia.

To the extent that long term unemployed may be less attractive to employers due to loss of job skills and work orientation, the lesser problem of long-term unemployment in Victoria may have enabled its overall unemployment rate to be reduced both faster and more easily.

(3) and (4) Various `barriers' exist to a common unemployment rate across States. One of the most important relates to the varying employment performance of respective States and the direct influence this has on unemployment outcomes, abstracting from labour force participation changes. Given the pattern of growth of aggregate demand, the composition of industry within States influences the extent to which employment can benefit from economic growth. Mismatches between jobseekers and available job vacancies may be another reason why the unemployment rate in certain States may be higher than the Victorian level. Through the Relocation Assistance Scheme (RAS) which aims to reduce geographical mismatching of jobs and jobseekers, and Government support for skills training (eg. the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training, the Adult Training Program, and the Community Training Program) the Government is directly attempting to improve the matching of jobseekers and job vacancies.

The uneven distribution of very long term unemployed across the States may present a `barrier' to reducing unemployment rates in some States to the Victorian level. For example, those unemployed for two years or more represent 0.9 per cent of the labour force in Victoria compared with 1.7 per cent in New South Wales. This may prevent the New South Wales unemployment rate being lowered to the Victorian level.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the ``Inherited extradition treaties listed by Mr Justice Stewart now been reviewed and a program of bilateral treaties negotiated'' following the Government's response to recommendation 56 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking; if so, with which countries have bilateral treaties been negotiated.
(2) What are the grounds of, and the procedures for, extradition with those countries.
(3) Has any effort been made by the Government to keep procedures with the various countries as uniform as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Extradition Task Force established by the Attorney-General in February 1985 has conducted a complete review of Australia's extradition arrangements. A program for the negotiation of modern extradition treaties to replace the inherited treaties and to put in place extradition arrangements where they presently do not exist is well advanced.

Since February 1985 modern extradition treaties have been signed with Ireland, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Norway. Protocols up-dating existing modern treaties have been signed with Sweden, Finland and Austria. The respective processes for bringing these treaties and protocols into force in Australia and each of those countries is now in progress.
By 30 June 1986, negotiations had resulted in the initialling by officials of treaty texts with France, Greece, Indonesia, Luxembourg, Monaco, Morocco, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Switzerland.
Negotiations are in progress with Algeria, Egypt, Israel, Philippines, South Korea, Tunisia, Turkey, United States of America.
Negotiations are due to commence shortly with Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombo, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay.

Expressions of interest in negotiating modern extradition treaties are being sought from other countries. In addition, since February 1985 the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 has been applied, pursuant to Sub-section 10 (4) of that Act, to Japan, Denmark, South Africa, and the Federal Republic of Germany, thus enabling Australia to make requests for extradition of, and consider requests for extradition by, those countries.

(2) (a) Under the treaties now being negotiated, extradition may be granted of a person accused or convicted of any offence punishable under the laws of both countries by a term of at least 12 months imprisonment, or by a more severe penalty. In the case of convicted persons, a minimum term of imprisonment, usually in excess of three months, must remain to be served. Extradition may be refused on a number of internationally accepted grounds, for example, that the offence of which the person is accused or convicted is an offence of a political character.

(b) The procedure for extradition under the treaties negotiated by Australia since February 1985 is simpler than the procedure under the older treaties. The modern procedure for extradition involves the making of a request in writing, accompanied by documents in support of the request. Section 17 of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966, the provisions of which are reflected in the modern treaties, specifies the minimum documentation which must be produced to a Magistrate to enable the making of an order. For example, the documentation comprises, in the case of an accused person, a copy of the warrant for the arrest of the person issued in the requesting country, a statement of the offences for which extradition is requested, a statement of the acts or omissions alleged against the person, particulars of identification, and a statement of the relevant provisions of law. The documentation must be authenticated in accordance with the treaty.

(3) A model treaty which was settled by the Extradition Task Force has been used as the basis for the negotiations which have been completed or are in progress. As a result, a substantial degree of uniformity has been attained. The procedures envisaged by the model treaty reflect the requirements specified in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966.

(2) With which countries has Australia negotiated treaties and/or agreements of the type outlined above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization taken to remedy deficiencies in its data processing management systems, which were highlighted in the report of the Auditor-General in 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In June 1984 the Organization launched a project to develop a new state of the art Payroll/Personnel system using a fourth generation language (NATURAL) and database management (ADABAS) approach. It was necessary that this project be completed and implemented in early 1985 to enable the existing payroll system, operating on the CSIRONET Cyber 76, to be replaced prior to the decommissioning of the Cyber 76.

As operating costs of the Cyber 76 were in the order of $1m per annum, CSIRONET did not wish to retain this computer simply for administrative work once the scientific computing was transferred to its replacements, the Cyber 205 and Cyber 840.

At that time the scheduled decommissioning of the Cyber 76 was targeted for May 1985 (although it was not ultimately decommissioned until November 1985). The Organization therefore faced a very stringent deadline for the introduction of a modern Payroll/Personnel system if it was to avoid the cost penalties of retaining the Cyber 76 in operation.

Following an extensive review of its administrative requirements it had been decided to replace all existing administrative computing systems, which were outdated batch systems and difficult to maintain, with new on-line interactive systems using ADABAS/NATURAL. The development and implementation of the Payroll/Personnel system, being the first of these new systems, involved not only the development of the necessary program software, but also the establishment and operation of interactive databases with all their security complexities, the setting up of a network of administrative terminals for on-line operations and the training of both computer systems staff and users.

The project was undertaken with emphasis on economy and against a stringent timetable. With hindsight, its introduction might be seen as having been premature, as all the necessary security features had not been put in place at the time of its introduction. While this resulted in audit criticism at that time, considerable progress has continued to be made since this audit review. Although refinements and developments in these areas will be an ongoing process to meet potential weaknesses that may be identified in the use of these new technologies, the concerted effort made by CSIRO to rectify problems which were identified after introducing the new system are believed to have remedied the deficiencies highlighted in the report of the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 October 1985 (Hansard, pages 1319-20), Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government consider introducing a provisional taxation system for this type of mineral exporter (referring to the Swiss-based Aluminium company Aluswisse) so that considerable funds would be held by the Government while any taxation appeals took place.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is not entirely clear from the question what the honourable Senator meant when he referred to a provisional taxation system. I have presumed, however, that he had in mind a system whereby a withholding of tax is made at the time a payment is made.

The Government recognises that deduction of tax at source can be a most cost-effective means of collecting tax. However, it is impractical to apply such a system in many instances, particularly where the relevant payments are for the sale of goods. The rate of withholding necessary from gross income to approximate the final tax liability on taxable income would be virtually impossible to calculate because of the many and varied circumstances of each individual taxpayer. Also, where income is received from a foreign source the withholding measures may not be able to be enforced.

Under existing law, a company that is unsuccessful in an appeal against a tax assessment, and which has not paid the tax which on appeal it is found liable to pay, is obliged to pay penalty tax at the rate of 20 per cent per annum. This tax is not an income tax deduction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2235) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer refers to the policy of granting tax exemptions to charitable organisations. Is the Minister aware that charitable organisations in Queensland-I refer specifically to the Queensland Deaf Society (Inc.) as a case in point-may be forced to pay up to $20,000 in new taxes under the new arrangements. What criteria has the Government applied in making exemptions to charitable organisations available to religious bodies but not to non-denominational organisations offering identical services? What response would the Minister make to the suggestion that the services of organisations like the Queensland Deaf Society are provided free to clients in need and that, therefore, any increases to the cost of such services cannot be handed on to the user?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 was amended in the Senate to exempt from fringe benefits tax benefits provided by public benevolent institutions to their employees.

The term ``public benevolent institution'' is not defined in that legislation but takes its meaning from common law. Broadly, such an institution is one which is organised for the relief of poverty, suffering, distress or misfortune and which is not conducted for the profit of individuals. The Queensland Deaf Society (Inc.) is recognised as a public benevolent institution and will thus be exempt from the fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2184) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Trade unions offer a wide range of benefits to their members including denticare, home loans and holiday homes. Do these benefits arise out of employment? If so, will they be subject to fringe benefits tax and who will pay the tax? If not, does the Government realise that benefits paid through an association allied to employment would provide a tax loophole?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Fringe benefits tax is a tax payable by employers on the value of certain benefits provided, either directly or indirectly, by the employer to an employee in respect of the employee's employment. The benefits referred to by the honourable senator arise in consequence of membership of the union and do not arise in consequence of the member's employment. Such benefits are therefore not subject to the tax. If, however, a union provided benefits to an official employed by the union in respect of the official's employment, the union would be liable to pay fringe benefits tax on those benefits in the same way as any other employer.

The Government does not accept that the situation as described represents a loophole in the fringe benefits tax law. The tax is not intended to apply to benefits that are not related to an employee's employment. In particular, the tax is not intended to apply where a person who is a member of a club, co-operative or other association that is not linked with an employer is able, by reason of his or her membership, to purchase goods or services at a lower price than if those goods or services were purchased by a non-member.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2325) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a pamphlet published by the Australian Sports Aid Foundation which is headed `Australia Bound for Edinburgh '86'. Inside the flyleaf it has a message from Mr Hawke imploring us all to support financially the Australian Commonwealth Games team which goes to Edinburgh this year in July. The pamphlet includes the statement:
The Australian Government has incorporated the Australian Sports Aid Foundation with the intention of making your donation to the team tax deductible.

Does this definitely mean that the money paid to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation is tax deductible? Secondly, is any other money paid to support the Australian Edinburgh team also tax deductible?

In a supplementary question, the honourable senator asked whether the Government is allowing people, through one of its own corporations, to make something tax deductible that would not otherwise be tax deductible.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1986 amended the gift provisions of the income tax law to authorise deductions for gifts of $2 or more, made on or after 18 February 1986, to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation. The Government established the Foundation to raise funds for the development of Australian sport generally.

Funds raised by the Foundation may be directed to those sports or sporting bodies considered by the Foundation to be most in need of assistance. It is not a requirement of the law that the bodies that receive funds from the Foundation qualify, in their own right, as organisations gifts to which are tax deductible.

Moneys paid in support of the Australian Commonwealth Games team may, in certain circumstances, be deductible under the existing general deduction provision of the income tax law. For expenditure to be so deductible, there must be a positive nexus between the incurring of the expenditure (the gift) and the production of assessable income or the carrying on of a business for that purpose. Where a taxpayer carrying on a business is able to demonstrate that a gift in support of the Australian Commonwealth Games team has been made to enhance the public image of that business, the expenditure would have the character of a business expense and be tax deductible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May 1986 (Hansard, page 3111) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Why is the Commissioner of Taxation issuing more than one assessment in respect of one or the same items of income?
(2) Does not this practice result in one assessment being inconsistent with the other and also in double taxation?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) & (2) The Commissioner of Taxation has confirmed that there are occasions when more than one assessment could possibly issue in respect of the same income. This could occur where the law is unclear and a decision of a court is necessary to decide the proper basis of assessment. The courts have recognised that in appropriate cases this multiple assessment action is open. In such cases, the Commissioner takes steps to avoid double taxation of the income by seeking payment only in respect of one of the relevant assessments until the matter is clarified. Once the correct basis of assessment is decided, any other assessment of the same income is withdrawn.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May 1986 (Hansard, page 3110), Senator Messner asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in today's Age that indicated that the Commissioner of Taxation is intending to raise 10,000 assessments against taxpayers involved with so-called bottom of the harbour tax avoidance schemes.
(2) Can the Minister confirm that report.
(3) If so, can the Minister advise on what basis such assessments will be raised.
(4) Are these assessments likely to be based on the same grounds as was the Hawke Labor Government's unreasonable legislation which has already been twice rejected by the Senate.
The Treasurer has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:
(1) Yes.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has confirmed that approximately 10,000 notices of assessment will issue to vendor-shareholders in respect of the sale of their shares in companies stripped of pre-tax profits.

(3) and (4) The assessments are being issued in reliance on section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Section 260 operates to make void, as against the Commissioner, a contract, agreement or arrangement made or entered into on or before 27 May 1981 to the extent to which it has or purports to have the effect of altering the incidence of income tax or of relieving any person from liability to pay any income tax.

The effect of section 260, in the context of pre-tax company profit stripping, is seen to be that the purported sale of the company shares is void as against the Commissioner so that the amount received by a shareholder that represents profits of the company of one kind or another is assessable as a dividend. Notices of assessment and adjustment sheets will reflect the inclusion of a dividend in assessable income.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 June 1986 (Hansard, page 3137) Senator Messner asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice regarding the concerns expressed by the Prime Minister recently at Canowindra about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the rural community, and in particular as it affects accommodation provided on farms. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the issues put to the Prime Minister at Canowindra and the Government sees no need to amend the fringe benefits tax as it applies to farmers. Many of the farmers' concerns were based on a misunderstanding of the intended application of the tax.

Certain lobby groups have sought to misrepresent and inflate the complexity and financial impact of the tax upon rural-based employers. The suggestion that farmers will have to pay fringe benefits tax on accommodation provided to children who work on the farm is just one of the more extreme suggestions put forward by these groups. I have also pointed out that the family homes of farmers will not be subject to the tax except in those circumstances where farmers claim tax deductions in relation to that home on the grounds that the farmer is in some sense an employee rather than the owner of the property. In fact, the concessions applying through the valuation principles built into the legislation would leave farmers with only a modest fringe benefits tax liability in most cases. Further, accommodation and power provided to employees in remote areas will attract a 40 per cent discount in recognition of the difficulties associated with remote area employment.

It should be remembered that the fringe benefits tax is intended to improve the fairness of our tax system. Without the fringe benefits tax those employees who can contract with their employers to receive a substantial part of their remuneration in the form of fringe benefits bear a proportionately smaller share of the tax burden than other employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1986 (Hansard, page 3348) Senator Zakharov asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice about a program of the Scotch College Foundation under which friends of the College make interest-free loans to the Foundation. Associated companies make them amongst themselves. The interest-free loans in the present case do not attract any income tax consequences to the members.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1986:

Subject to the constraints of staffing and other resources I would hope to continue to develop that most valuable practice.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Covenants Ratified by Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are only two United Nations Covenants to which Australia is a party, namely the Covenants on Civil and Political Rights, and on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. There are, however, a number of other multilateral treaties, sometimes termed ``conventions'', for which the Secretary-General of the United Nations performs depositary functions or which have been drawn up by specialised agencies of the United Nations, and to which Australia has become a party by ratification or by some other step provided for in the treaty concerned, such as definitive signature, accession or acceptance. These treaties are set out in the attached list.

(2) The dates on which Australia became a party to the multilateral treaties by ratification or otherwise are entered on the right of the list. This information is also available in the Australian Treaty List (published in the Australian Treaty Series 1971 No. 1) and subsequent cumulative supplements and annual lists of treaty actions published in the treaty series.

(3) The list of states party to multilateral treaties is voluminous and in some cases, for example where a reservation has been made, requires interpretation. The information may be found in United Nations publication `Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General' and in publications of the specialised agencies. The Treaties and Sea Law Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs can provide information on particular treaties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Defence been drawn to a report in The Age of Monday 2 June 1986 quoting recently declassified Pentagon documents revealing that the United States Navy accidently released nuclear weapons in each of the years 1965, 1968, 1969 and 1970.
(2) Are any details available on the United States Navy's safety record from 1970 to the present day.
(3) Have any of the United States Navy's nuclear accidents happened in Australian or South Pacific waters.
(4) What measures are in place to ensure Australia is not vulnerable to nuclear accidents involving visiting United States warships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for De- fence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The United States Navy has acknowledged that during the period 1965-1985 its nuclear weapons accident reporting system received 630 reports of ``mishaps''. The United States uses a stringent system of reporting all mishaps, however small, including those involving dummy weapons used in training.

Of the 630 mishaps, only two could properly be classified as nuclear weapon accidents; both involved the loss of weapons at sea. One was the loss overboard of a nuclear armed A4E fighter in the Western Pacific. The other occurred in 1968 in the North Atlantic.

Of the other mishaps, 364 involved dummy weapons used for training purposes. The remaining 264 mishaps were minor, consisting of such events as flat tyres on trailers, and sprinkler systems in magazines being inadvertently activated. None involved leakage of radioactivity.
(3) There have been no nuclear weapons accidents in Australian waters nor any, as far as the Australian Government is aware, in South Pacific waters.

(4) Nuclear powered warship (NPW) visits to Australia only take place in accordance with the Australian Government's general conditions of entry. In accordance with these conditions, NPWs are permitted to visit only those ports which have been assessed as suitable in terms of strict environmental and safety criteria. Within these ports, the conditions of entry require that NPWs and other shipping be subject to special navigational controls designed to minimize the likelihood of any mishap. Any port to be visited by an NPW must have in place an operating port safety organisation which includes a suitable radiation monitoring program.

Details of these port safety plans vary in accordance with local conditions and administrative arrangements. However, they cover arrangements for routine and emergency radiation monitoring and protection, co-ordination of emergency services, evacuation, public information and the removal of the vessel to a remote location.

Arrangements for other types of accidents are covered in the general emergency plans for harbour accidents which exist for every Australian port. These plans utilise the resources of the port emergency services, including fire brigades, police and health agencies, along with State, Territory and Commonwealth support as appropriate.
